content.p: There is no industry standard middleware protocol. A standard protocol is necessary for interoperability and competition between vendors' implementations.
A reference server implementation is the only way to verify that the standard wire-level protocol is well-formed and feasible to implement.
content.h2: Build a Set of Client APIs
content.p: Creating a set of client APIs saves developers the cost of learning the wire-level protocol. There exist industry-standard APIs, such as JMS, which we (will) conform to.
OpenAMQ is designed as an open source project that will promote the AMQP protocol and the AMQ standard architecture.

ul.li: Multiplexes channels over a single socket connection
Handles messages of any size by fragmentation
Messages are handled as opaque binary data, tagged with MIME types for application use
Fully asynchronous flow of data between client and server
Negotiation of server and client capabilities
Ability to pass data using out-of-band techniques (zero-copy)

content.p: The OpenAMQ server has these features:

ul.li: Portable to Linux, Solaris, Unix, Win32
Built in ANSI C, using iMatix technology

content.p: The OpenAMQ client APIs have these features:

ul.li: Providing a JMS-like interface, with extensions

content.p: The OpenAMQ open source project is still under construction.
